column11: Review Text
Quite nice, hardly any guide here, but not to compare with the botanical garden in Peradheniya.Easily done from Nuwara Eliya

Pure waste of money $11 per person. Looks like normal garden. No good information on plants., flowers. Labels are present somewhere, absent elsewhere. We spotted a snake moving on the road. So be careful. Any botanical garden like Lalbaugh in Bangalore, Ooty's garden, Coonoor's garden are way better maintained than this. This is totally avoidable.

column8: Peaceful Garden Escape, Even in the Rain
column11: I visited Hakgala Botanical Garden in Nuwara Eliya after a late lunch, and even though it was raining, the experience was worth it. The garden is beautifully laid out with a variety of flowers, tall trees, and greenery that creates a calm and refreshing atmosphere. The rain made it difficult to take clear photos and I couldnâ€™t explore the plantation area properly, but it also added a quiet charm â€” the sound of raindrops among the flowers was very peaceful. The entrance fee for foreign adults was about LKR 3,000, which I felt was reasonable for the beauty you get. Hakgala is perfect for anyone who enjoys nature, gardens, and a calm escape from the busy town. I would recommend visiting on a clearer day to really appreciate the colors and views, but even in the rain it was memorable. Tip: Wear comfortable shoes, as paths can be slippery in wet weather, and bring an umbrella if you visit during rainy season.
Spent 2 weeks in Sri Lanka. One of the places we visited is this botanical garden. If you have enough time....include this garden in your things to visit.
Amazing place. Beautiful flowers We took the buggy and the person who driving was such a wonderful human, kudos to such people.
Quite an interesting place.  You can hire a golf cart if you donâ€™t want to walk.  Variety of plants, flowers and trees.  Not very crowded.  It was a pleasant experience.

column8: Visit if you are in Nuwara Eliya,Don't explicitly plan for this.
column11: Visited in  April 2024. Well, it's beautiful,  how usually botanical gardens are. Some amazing views with hills in background. We took baby stroller, so some slopes were tricky. If you are from India , and been to Ooty, you can think of this place as Botanical garden in ooty. We covered Ashok Vatika and this place the same day. The toilets were hideous.

column8: a lovely place to walk and see the gardens around. orchids, cactus and canyon ball trees and very old and big trees.
column11: Such a beautiful garden.  well maintained and a large place with different species of plants, flowers and gardens. you only have to do a lot of walking which is good so wear comfy walking shoes and wear caps if you are going in the summer.

column8: Another very good visit to the gardens
column11: My wife an I enjoyed another very good visit to the Hakgala Botanic Gardens, despite the inclement weather. The roses were in particularly good bloom.

column8: It's a okay garden, nothing special, but clean and well maintained.
column11: It's a okay garden, nothing special, but clean and well maintained. But a scam for tourists, where you will pay 30-50 times more than what the locals pay.

It was a great experience in the botanical gardens. The variety of flora is amazing. Loved the fernery which host so many different kinds of ferns. Interesting the botanical garden also has a variety of birds coming regularly to do good bird photography or bird watching. Enjoyed the visit
A beautiful garden with a lot of flowers of different varieties. Since the place is cold you will enjoy a walk around the gardens.

Visited Hakgala after few years. There are new development from the entrance. Specialy this time Rose gardens were full of flowers. Everywhere you can see diferant colour of roses. The newly built Rose garden also anice arrangement to see

We went in to kill time prior to going on the train and we were delighted that we did! Relatively small but very nicely laid out with classic English flowers that were in full bloom - sweet peas, sweet william, busy lizzies, holly hocks, dahlias etc it was a true delight and very relaxing
Enjoy a pleasant place, beauty, brilliance and intelligent nature.  I loved it and sat there for a long time and breathed a lot of fresh air..
The cactus and succulent house was the highlight for us. Our 7 month old enjoyed the colourful roses. The garden has a lot of potential to attract more visitors.
As usual. Nice flower garden. But may end is not the most suitable time for visit there. Better try April month. Nice roses!

Very well designed garden with many beautiful walkways. Abundance of flowers and trees. Good idea for planning small picnic and bring own food and drinks. Compared to Kandy this garden is even more attractive.
Great place to observe different kind of flora and fauna!. This is  just a 30 minutes journey from Nuwara Eliya Town.  A must visit place during your Nuwara Eliya Trip

This story is about a beautiful experience i had when i was in high school. Even though the school teachers say it's an educational trip, it's a really a fun trip for us. One day we took abus to cold Nuwara Eliya with my friends. We sang and danced until we reached the tourist spots, but after getting of the bus, we made sure to preserve the school's reputation. The first stop on the trip is the Peradeniya Botanic Garden. There was a special reasonto choose the botanical garden. It's a " landscaping " lesson. We looked closely at the different methods plants were grown on a large scale. Whatever the plants, it was beautifully cultivated to a certain patters. The next stop was the " Adisham Bungalow" in Bandarawela, Badulla.  It is a flower garden in the fullest sense of the word. The eyes are unbelievably pink. Surrounding plne plants. Phineas is a plant that i reallt love, even if it's meaningless. Finally we entered Hakgala park. Many foreign tourists also came to seeit. As the day was coming to an end, I bega to feel the coolness of the environment. I walked around the garden and saw the beauty of the flowers and palnts and did not forget to take photos with my friends in the evening, everyone gathered in one place and the other school friends sang ang danced in the garden. The teachers looked at me with a smile and i went to one side and applauded and sang school time is the foundation of the future life. There is no doubt that the experience gained through it will never be forgotten.
We visited this in December so  it wasn't in its usual splendor! The garden was in the midst of a face lift in preparation for the April season. A peaceful place to visit with family.
March is off season for flowers. the rose garden was completely closed. not worth the time and effort to visit Hakgala during March .
We visited during March and not much of flowers we to be seen, rose garden was completely closed.. not worth the walk and trouble

This is the off season. So there werenâ€™t much flowers and the staff were preparing for the spring. So during this time of the year this place is not the ideal place to see flowers. But they have beautiful landscapes of huge trees. I will definitely recommend going to this place only for those trees. They were that pretty and magnificent. For flowers like roses etc ideal time would be March -April. But if anyone is in the area this is a must. But as a person who has visited this place multiple times I have to say that they still havenâ€™t reached their full potential. They are developing the place. I wish they do that without harming the natural environment in the area.
This is a much smaller garden with the same 2000LKR per foreign adult entry ticket. Paredenia Botanical Garden ,Kandy is 100 times better and worth the entry ticket

WE had the advantage of a lovely day at these gardens. I suggest a buggy which is cheap to cover the entire gardens. We stopped by a number of attractions here. There was the cactus and succulents gardens which was worth. It was not rose season as we were told it blooms in April. albeit was worth spending half a day here. thia is also a bird watchers paradise
A nice way to spend an hour or so strolling the park  , indoor and outdoor plants and  cheap to enter !
Must visit for people who Love Roses and Flowers - we had a good day out at the park but it started to rain after we entered - had lunch and then left as it was raining heavily

HAKGALA Botanic Gardens in Sir Lanka is not like other botanical gardens I visited before. The variety and organization of the garden is something noticeable. Although I  visited during December and itâ€™s not a preferable seasons. Iâ€™m very impressed about it and number of plants planted and the size of the garden. If I will suggest something it will be about the signage of direction that can be improved and enhanced. Also if you had a chance to visit during April - July will be even better since it is spring and will see the flowers totally different.

This is an amazing botanical garden outside Nuwara Eliya. We loved exploring the small paths up the hill, especially the fern garden. Definitely worth a visit (ideally when you aren't pressed for time).

It is a very good garden but hilly and you have to be physically fit to spend 2.5 hrs walking around to admire the garden. Alternative you can rent a golf cart with driver for 2 person total 1000 rupees for 1hr. Entrance fee for foreigners is 2500 per person some usd 15. First time to see green roses. Recommended
Nice and best beautiful garden in nuwaraeliya. 50 rupees for local. Need 2-3 hours. Well maintain. lots of nice places to get photos. Must go if you visit nuwaraeliya.

We went to the Botanic gardens on a rainy day. If you walk up a distance to the office you could get a golf cart to take you around. We had to wait quite a while as there were only 3 golf carts. Charges are 1000 or 2000 depending on size of the cart. The gardens do not have lots of flowers. The major part are trees a Fernery,rock garden,arboretum.  There is a small rose garden and glass house with begonias and orchids and cacti.

Entry ticket for foreigners is lrk 2k which is again not worth. The garden is big enough with good flowers, although for the money taken , we could only see the same flowers spread across all areas of the garden. As a tourist, I expect a bit more variety. We could see some wild flowers which were every where on the streets as well( nothing new) The govt. Should think of lowering their ticket prices for foreigners, else no body would be interested to see something which can also been see else where on the street. Its well maintained, with not much crowd. Location is beautiful, has hills surrounding it with a lot of moneys. Recommended only if you enjoy a walk in the park spending a good amount.
Noting to rave about.  Not worth the Rs. 2000 one has to fork out.  In other countries entrance fees for parks/gardens like this are very much lower or even free.
There were lots of winding paths that led to beautiful gardens. The rose garden was amazing. Roses with colors that I had never seen before.

It charged foreigner 2k Rupee, it is pricey I must say, do it if you are really free. It is not particularly impressive, I had a leisure walked around and taking pictures of the flowers. There are lots of tall trees around, I am not a fan of plants /trees, so it is just an average garden for me. Perhaps I went to others in other countries that charge lesser or even free.
relaxing walk through well maintained gardens. A very pleasant way to see lots of local plants and features.

Situated at 16km from Nuwara Eliya on Nuwara Eliya - Badulla Road. Well maintained with an attractive rose garden.  Disposable plastic bottles not allowed to be taken inside.   Some pathways are steep and may be difficult for the elderly.  Electric golf cart (4-7 passenger) may be available with driver/guide for hire. Parking only along the main road, entry and exit at two different locations.

Huge. Huge. Huge. Keep strolling! Keep strolling! Visited this garden during SL trip with family. The garden truly amazed me in the way it was kept amidst the lap of nature. It is surrounded by hills on almost all sides and being located @ 5000+ ft above MSL, provides the right type of cold climate required for the garden to blossom. You will just be surprised on how many varieties of flowers & trees, our nature can provide us. The garden houses thousands of varieties of plants, trees, flowers, ferns, cactus etc. It is spread over, minimum 25 acres of land, I presume. The garden charges same entrance fee to all SAARC and non-SAARC visitors. It opens @ 0800hrs and winds up @ 1730hrs. The nursery - for shopping - shall close by 1500hrs. You can spent a lot of time in the well laid out sections of the garden like Bulb garden, Rose Garden, Glass House, Fernery, Rock Garden etc. Date of Experience : March 2019.

Hakgala Botanical Garden is nearer to Nuwara Eliya and it is one of big botanical garden in Sri Lanka. Various types of Plants and trees are there in this garden.It is one of the tourist attraction place in Nuwara Eliya.
Hakgala Garden is well structurally maintained with a massive collection of bio assets such as trees and flowers. its a paradise for nature lovers and the climate was awesome.

The last time I visited the Hakgala gardens I was a teenager and this time I visited it with my toddler boys. It was beautifully maintained and it was exactly how I remembered it. We found it hard to walk around with the kids and we took the fantastic buggy service that was available and was able to see the entire garden (some parts that I didnâ€™t even know that existed). The driver of the buggy gave us information on the history of the gardens which I thought was really great as we previous have not had that opportunity.

A perfect place for gardens as itâ€™s so nice to walk in the windy n chilly temperature! Flowers were blooming so beautiful, wind brushing against our hair and faces, trees were green, gardens were nicely sculpted. We love this place!
It is the second largest botanical garden in Sri Lanka and worth a visit if you are in Nuwara Eliya. Try to take the buggy service as it is easy and joyful.
The gardens have some amazing flora and fauna from every nook and corner of the world. Save yourself at least 1.5 hours and wear comfortable footwear

These Gardens are beautifully maintained and the colours of all the flowers are amazing. In another area there are majestic trees and, if you are lucky, you will see bear monkeys, which are large but shy. One suggestion would be to have better signage.

A huge number and range of flowers, trees and shrubs, many of which we are familiar with in UK, but somehow these were bigger and brighter. Also saw a large troop of monkeys both large and small babies. They come down to eat the foliage and are shooed away by the staff. However, they came very close to us and ran across the paths in front of us.

lovely park in Nuwara Eliya,climate too good,had to pay for the entrance tickets,the garden cleaners told us that the April is the best month to visit the park,so many flowers are blooming at that time,nice landscapes,very attractive park,decent and lovely,good for honeymoon couples,we enjoyed lot

The gardens are quite different to what you will see at Peridiniya due to the cooler climate. It is still very much based around the traditional English style with elements of a cottage garden feel with the flowers on display. For heritage gardens such as these the management of the plant material as it ages is critical to maintaining its integrity. Unfortunately these gardens are really passed their best with the Cyprus trees in varying stages of decline as with the large rhododendron plantings towards the back of the property. The Japanese garden is not a good example and the roses if in bloom when you visit add colour but with no real design. There are some interesting endemic species that can be seen with the history behind gardenâ€™s establishment of greater interest. Entrance cost for foreign visitors is 1500Rps which is a little in the expensive side for what you really see. As something to do while visiting a few days you might want to consider visiting, otherwise give it a miss.
A super cool garden. I love this garden just because it has many subtropical and tropical plants. Garden is spread across 68 acres with a huge variety of trees, plants and pretty flowers and more.

Large botanic garden established in 19th century, with impressive old trees and many plants from all over the world. Worth a visit when you are around Nuwara Eliya. Adult foreigners pay 1500 LKR, foreign kids 750 LKR.
Good park with lots of photo ops. However, lack of sitting areas, access to water and food makes things bitter for those carrying along kids. Booking of ekarts is not transparent.

It was lovely to visit Hakgala Botanical garden, They are providing golf cart services for a  small cost such as 7 US dollers and you can visit entire garden by your own buggy On the way they are providing some important information about gardan , plants and history, When you travel with a golf car you will not going to miss anywhere. Lovely wether , You can see rock garden , Rose garden , Hurbal garden etc. Highly recomand to visit Hakgal Botanical garden when you are traveling in Nuwara eliya.

Had a lovely visit here - luckily we were able to hire a golf cart and driver as the gardens are quite hilly and I have walking difficulties.  Beware of the toilets as the ones I visited were the hole in the floor type - eeeeek.
The botanical garden is rather a bigger garden however not too many attractions. Not worth the time nor the money.

These beautifully maintained gardens are only a short drive from Nuwara Eliya. They feature any extensive array of flora from all over the globe. Lawns and flower beds are all well cared for. Towards the back of the park, near the Japanese Gardens a group os resident monkeys provide some entertainment for visitors. Easy walking trails packed with beautiful scenery. A great place to relax and enjoy a well maintained garden.

Had great morning visiting gardens, well laid out and organised and exceptional variety on show !TIP.   Although we walked round there were golf buggy tours available at a reasonable cost that we would have used if we had known about them.

Long walking was not convenient for my family so we chose to visit this garden for their golf cart service/ tour. For an additional 1,000 Rs. (we were a group of 6 persons) we had an actual botanist (Dr. Herath?) drive and guide us around, sharing and explaining about the different plants, native and non-native to Sri Lanka/ Asia. Ask and he'll give you both scientific and common names of any plant you point to. He also demonstrated how parts of certain plants could be used for health and/ or beauty purpose. There is a little nursery where you can buy plants and seeds at a reasonable price. A small and very well-maintained botanical garden. We went during planting season yet still left impressed. Blooming/ flowering season from April to December would be perfect timing.

My wife and I spent the morning here during our recent Birdwatching Tour of Sri Lanka ðŸ‡±ðŸ‡°. Our visit coincided with a major planting exercise for the forthcoming holiday season, so we didnâ€™t see the gardens at their finest, this didnâ€™t bother us as our main for visiting was the 'Bird' the Gardens. What we did see of them was impressive, theyâ€™re very well laid out and beautifully maintained. We managed to see several of the more common local species including Dull-blue Flycatcher and Purple-faced Leaf Monkey (Langur) and the rare Chestnut-backed Owlet. A Black Eagle flew over the escarpment as we arrived. A very enjoyable visit and well maintained paths. Highly Recommended.
Excellent view and many more to enjoy with the nature inside the garden even the Japan garden and the green house was fantastic and love it visit again

A nice peaceful botanical garden with lots is cedar trees and tree ferns, but something of an anti-climax after having visited the Royal Botanical Gardens at Peradeniya. It maybe that February is not a good month to visit because there was little colour to be seen even though there were many plants that must flower at other times of the year (there were, for example, a number of well set-out rose gardens but not a rose flower in sight).

It's one one old botanical gardens and it's has very old trees unbelievable lovely flowers you can spend around four hours inside the park. It's the nature of our beautiful country Sri Lanka you must visit the experience you get.
We enjoyed the trip of botanical garden but unfortunately flowers were not there because of season . In different locations we found chairs for sitting so that one can relax in between

Maybe it was the time of year but, we were not impressed. From looking at the other reviews we expected more. The price did not help either!! Seems like being a tourist in Sri Lanka sometimes feels like your being taken advantage of. I paid 1500 rupees, my Sri Lankan wife paid 60.. Oh well

Just off the famous Nuwereliya, if you someone who loves peace and tranquility, then it is a place to be. Takes you out of the Buzz in the city, and gives you calm environment to enjoy. During spring, there will be 100s of rosses, and are mesmerizing.

If you go nuwaraeliya,this is must see place. No need to take a taxi. Every minute there is a bus to go and and back. Within 15 minutes you can reach to the park entrance. A ticket for a foriegner is 1500LKR, but its really worth. Full tour inside the park is around 2-3 hours. If you go march-July there are a lots of flowers can see. Thise are amazing. Otherthan flowers there are more than 5000 trees, plants and insects can be seen. Garden is cold throughout the year. If you wany you can hire a cart to go around the garden but my recommendation is do walk.

If you like your gardens then this is a must, entry fee is 1500 rupees and will take around 2 to 3 hours to walk the grounds, there are golf buggy type carts you can hire to take you round, 500 rupees for a couple, monkeys are all over and funny to watch, only thing lacking is a real cafe, there is a cafe but very limited food available. We visited in January and this is planting time so limited flowers to see but the grounds are incredible to walk
If you travel to nuwaraeliya you shoul visit that place.you can get very good knowledge of lot of varieties of plants and florals.

We went to see the garden in eaely februari. That is the time for planting. There were few flowers. But we can see that in March/April  there will be lots of flowers. The Arboretum is very impressive with many species and well marked. Entry fee us 1500 rupies which is on the high side. Easy to reach by bus. Certainly back towards Nuwara Eliya there is a bus every  minutes.

Visited here on Jan 23rd,2019. As per folklore, the Sri Lankan demon King Ravana after abducting Sita, kept her hidden in this area and this area was offered to Sita as a pleasure garden, the place finds mention in the Ramayana as Ashok Vatika. This place is of special cultural significance to Indians!

A popular tourist spot with easy access by public transport. Hakgala is the second largest botanical garden in Sri Lanka. Well maintained garden with over 10,000 species. Nuwaraeliya is one of the coolest areas in the island so walk along the paths was never tiring. Being a heavy fan of roses and orchids, I'm happy with the collection. Sign boards with well defined maps make sure that you won't miss anything. Glad that went during the blooming season to see the real beauty. If you feel to take some flowers home, do not pluck them. Buy some seeds from the  little plant nursery inside the park for to grow your own. In fact, its cheap. There are few small stalls to grab some  drinks and snack at the entrance. Must to add to your bucket list.
Get the public bus from the station and for 40 rupees you will arrive! The gardens are well kept and itâ€™s nice to see house plants in the UK growing outside! Itâ€™s definitely worth the visit..
A walk in the park is the best you could do in this area; it is 68 acres in area and established during the British regime in 1838. We used a Golf Cart to accomplish to cover the area.

Large site that is being carefully and sympathetically developed.  Lots of beautiful trees, and plenty of flower planting going on.  By April I think it will look very attractive, when the plants have grown and are in flower.  We were very happy to follow the paths and stretch our legs after being in the car for some time.

As the park is big and we had limited time, we chose to do the tour with the large 6 seater buggy. We were fortunate that our driver had an intricate knowledge of the history , plants and trees. There is so much to see and nature lovers could spend days exploring this wonderful garden

The First Issue I had Here was, At the Ticket Counter they said me that there is a Shuttle inside to go Around the Garden, But when I went in up the Officers said that the Shuttle's battery is down so for the day there is no More shuttle.. When I complained Saying that At the Ticket Counter they promised me for the Shuttle but when I come there is no shuttle, One of the Officers were very Kind and He gave the Permission to Take my Own Car in to go around the Garden . That was Really Appreciated, because it was So Raining as well.. In my Point of view, More than the shuttle or the Car I prefer Walking..
excellent and huge garden with variety of plants and flowers.nice place for photography and roam around for 3-4 hours.
It is a lovely place, especially for botanics. Otherwise nice place to take pictures among beautiful flower

The gardens cover a wide area and it is quite steep if you walk all of it. Unfortunately, this time of the year, the gardens were not seen at their best. We still enjoyed an hour or so being driven around in the golf buggy, which we shared the cost with two strangers. It is pretty cheap. Some lovely views to the mountains make for good photo opportunities.
Great place to spend a day. But we had to wait for more than an hour for the golf car to come around for us.
I love this garden because it has many subtropical and tropical plants, pretty flowers, centuries-old trees, and more. It's such a great place to be in contact with nature!

Those gardens are extremely famed for their beautiful plants and flowers, especially the roses and orchids. In fact, I can totally understand why so many people enjoy it. It is such a gorgeous landscape with beautiful sceneries! I definitely recommend it to anyone.

May be this garden is sold telling as Ashok Vatika or some other important place where events occurred during Ramayana. It is a simple garden and nothing else. Charges are very high for foreigners.. so can be avoided.

Worth a visit if in Nuwara Eliya area. Parking was a bit difficult. Tickets need to be purchased for entry. Some areas are in regeneration phase, the tropical garden section was excellent - even saw ~3m snake, not sure if it was  venomous or not.
If you are travelling from Nuwara Eliya to Welimada, worth visit it. Otherwise you may skip this. Nothing exceptional. But should say the garden is lovey.

Is this botanical garden nice? Yes, it is. Is it amazing? No, definitely not. You park along the road (can be long walk if you're unlucky) and then at the gate you're welcomed by hefty 1500 LKR "tourist price" where "local" price is 20 times lower... Is it worth the price? NO! Nice collection of flowers, but being very honest, some hotel gardens on our trip were as nice (or maybe even better) thank this botanic garden. Hill walk, so not for those with walking problems.

This is a must see. Golf carts are available & must be used because the driver is also a good guide who can educate you about the flora & fauna. Neatly labled garden with local, international species surviving. Supposed to be associated with great Indian epic Ramayana.

The Entry fee is 1500 Srilanka RS, then after entering the gardens & few minutes uphill walk buggies are available for hire(@250 srilankan RS per head) to take one around,  the gardens are on hilly terrain so could be an issue for the elderly or unfit to walk.The gardens close by 5 pm..best time to visit would be mornings.
This one is not as great as the botanical garden in Colombo and a good stop for relaxing in the arms of nature
Gardens failed to live up to its name. There was no sense of order and variety was minimum. Private gardens owned by residents and hotels in same area are much nicer.
This botonical garden is not as great as one in Colombo however good for relaxing and evening walk..

Hakgala is a must visit park but must be aware the entry fees for non-residents is LKR 1500 per head and LKR 750 for Kids. It is similar to any botanical garden but well maintained and beautiful place to spend some good time. For seniors and young kids, they can opt for Battery operated cars(10 Seater -LKR 1000, 5 Seater - LKR 500)

This botanical garden is certainly worth visiting. It is quite large, so be prepared to do some walking. Many different sections to enjoy and we really loved the Japanese garden and the fernery. The cost for foreign tourists is a bit expensive, but when you see how beautifully the garden is maintained you won't be upset to have contributed. They do not allow plastic water bottles inside.
Beautiful place with lots of colourful flowers. But the entrance fee is way too expensive for tourists. Compared to Peradiniya botanical park, this is smaller but fee is higher.
All the trip is free. They take you to the tea fields with a friendly guide then to the factory and show you every step.. then tea tasting then you can buy from their shop

This is probably the most beautiful botanic garden Iâ€™ve seen, anywhere in the world. The massed displays of flowers just went on and on! There is also an arboretum section that is atmospheric, if not as stunning. Really worth a visit!

Rs300 for travelers, Rs400 for locals. I understand it is a means to help travelers subsidise the upkeep of the gardens but that seemed a little much of a difference to me. Gardens could be stunning though they do hark back to the British times with many European flowers (roses, etc) and little that is native to the Nuwara Eliya region.

Hakgala Botanical Garden is situated on the Nuwara Eliya-Badulla main road, 16 km from Nuwara Eliya. The garden has a cool temperate climate because of altitude is 5,400 feet above the sea level. The mean annual temperature ranges between 16 Â°C to 30 Â°C during course of a year. From December to February it has a cold climate, while the warm climate persists from April to August.
It is quite a nice garden. There are nice streams in the park. I like Peradeniya Garden (near Kandy) better.
Excellent trees and sound with calm and relaxed. Well maintained grass roots and park street. Just make a walk
Need at least 04 hrs if you are to cover the entire area on foot.  A place not to be missed, and can be considered a younger sister of the majestic Peradeniya Gardens.
A lovely amazing garden.. trees are 150 years old with the origin of each documented.. Japanese gardenis wonderful

In srilanka there are several gardens where visitors can see different plants herbs treed. One such place is Hakgala botanic garden. Another important thing is that it is located higher altitude than other garden,s . so some varieties are unique to the area When you go via Kandy you have to go passing nuwaraeliya about 10 km. But if you come from Badulla or Bandarawela you come across this garden before the city Nuwaraeliya. At the entrance you have to buy a ticket.Trees plants are named and labeled. There are benches and seats to rest. There is a canteen. But there is not much selections.Only some  are available. Before going buy what you like.
It is big park. The ticket price reasonable. It's great place to walk between trees and flowers. Some areas are closed due to maintenance. We spent more than two and half hour and never get bored.
Overshadowed by the Peradeniya garden, Hakgala lies on the bank of Hakgala mountain sporting an admirable collection of endemic and foreign fauna.

The 2nd hill country botanic gardens after Peradeniya Gardens, which was originally a plantation of Cinchona from which the anti-malarial drug quinine was found and later used for experiments in acclimatizing temperate-zone plants to life in the tropics, and were run by the same family for three generations, up to the 1940. Hakgala Botanical Gardens is located 10 km away from the town of Nuwara Eliya. Your trip to Nuwara Eliya is not complete without a visit to the Hakgala Gardens mainly because the site is legendary. It was once the pleasure garden of Ravana of the Ramayana epic and according to many, it was one of the places where the beautiful Sitha was hidden by the demon King Ravana. The present botanic gardens were founded in 1860 by the eminent British botanist Dr. G.H.K. Thwaites who was superintendent of the Peradeniya Gardens. The Garden consists of an outstanding collection of fauna and flora.

A very scenic garden on a hill; one of the 5 botanical gardens in Srilanka, and this place is just 1 km from Sita temple. A good hang out place for family and kids. This park has a wide range of flowers and plants, it also has categories like Rose garden, Japanese garden,etc. It was like an Amazon forest kind of place, it also has some cute bridges and small waterfalls running all over the park.
Located just outside Nuwaraeliya  city. Lots of plants, flowers, trees. Nice Landscape. If any one cannot walk can hire golf car. Nice view over mountains

Haggala botanical garden located in Nuwaraeliya district. So many beautiful flowers and beautiful trees. The Hakgala Botanic Garden, just outside of Nuwara Eliya, is definitely worth a visit. As some have noted, the entry fee for foreigners (LKR1500) may seem a little expensive, but as a visitor, you can see where the entrance fee is going. An army of gardeners keeps this place very well tended. The garden is at an altitude of around 1700 metres, and features a lot of temperate plants and trees. Monterrey Cypresses features prominently here, but there are also Bunya Bunya Pines and Norfolk Island Pine Trees from Australia. There's a rose garden, several greenhouses, a rock garden, and also a Japanese garden. I thought the Japanese garden was lovely, but struggled to see much relation to traditional Japanese gardens. There is also a section of the garden that was part of a tea plantation, where camellia sinensis trees have been allowed to grow out. I was fascinated to see them, as they grow to 10 - 13 metres once they're no longer pruned tightly. I'd recommend getting to the gardens early, as they are pretty popular. There's a small canteen inside, but there are a lots of small shops immediately outside the gates. I'll let the photos of this place speak for themselves...

If you are really in to nature, then I would recommend that you do allocate a full day to cover the entire garden and be mesmerized not only with the beauty of the plants within, but with the span of the horizon that can be seen from the garden, and how the weather conditions change, with a moment of mist, and moment of no mist. I personally did see many butterflies, birds and two different types of monkeys. If you are a photography enthusiast, and then have the equipment right, then you would be able to take many photos of birds, butterflies, monkeys, flowers as well as macro shots (if you really in to it). Hakgala gardens is few kilometres away from the Nuwara Eliya town. It is spread across a vast area of land and quite nicely maintained. During the time at which I went there , the rose garden and some parts of the garden was being renovated. Best time to visit the garden would be starting from April since it is the season in Nuwara Eliya. Normally from December to February they will replant everything in order to get ready for the season. There is a small shop in the gardens where you can buy plants. There are a lot of places you can walk in the garden and also they have a mini cab service inside the garden as well.

If you love nature, this garden is definitely worth the trip. ENTRANCE: The line for the tickets can be a bit unruly - crowds just hanging in front of the window to collect tickets.  Tickets can be a little pricey, especially if you are not a local.  Having said that, it may be worth what you pay for. TRANSPORTATION: Since the garden is quite extensive, you can hire a buggy to take you around the park.  This may be a good option if you are a family with elders or toddlers who may tend to get tired with long walks.  They are priced reasonable and can be hired from near the entrance. PARK: You are provided with a map of the garden.  Definitely recommended as some of the areas you might miss out on if you are not referring to the map.  Some areas of the park give you a good view of the city from up above - definite photo opportunity.  When we visited, the flowers and plants were still blooming, so colors were a little limited.  Nevertheless, it was still a fulfilling experience. You may also see family of monkeys - just be careful if you are holding any edible items - they may come and grab it.  But for the most part, they keep to themselves. FOOD: There was a small canteen that served drinks, crisps and other food items.  Nice spot to catch your breath a little, view the surroundings. OVERALL: A good visit if you have an hour or two to spare.

Hakgala Botanical Garden is one of the five botanical gardens in Sri Lanka. It is the second largest garden in Sri Lanka. The garden is contiguous to Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve. Hakgala Botanical Garden is situated on the Nuwara Eliya-Badulla main road, 16 km from Nuwara Eliya. Hakgala Botanic Gardens, about 28 hectares in extent, lie under the shadow of the Hakgala Rock. The garden was established in 1861, under George Henry Kendrick  as an experimental cultivation of Cinchona, a comercial crop thriving at the time. Once after the Tea replaced the Cinchona, it was turned into an experimental Tea cultivation. In 1884 it transformed to a garden. Since then many sub tropical and some temperate plants were planted in the gardens. The Botanic Gardens are locally reputed for their collection, the rose garden, Magnificent trees, indoor plants, flowers. The climate of the Gardens is subtropical, cool and freshThere are over 10,000 species of flora planted here. However USD 12.5 for SARC coumtries and USD 25.00 per person for a foreigner is bit expensive.

We really loved walking through one particular narrow path that went through trees and felt as if we were in a forest. With nobody else around, we just had so much fun. As the light faded we started looking for the way back but got lost. We didn't panic though and enjoyed our search for the exit. The management should add exit signs in some of the remote places to guide visitors because there is only one entrance/exit and these Botanic Gardens are spread over an enormous area.

We decided to give this garden a visit on our first Sri Lanka trip. It is located about 30minutes from Nuwara Eliya town. This botanical garden is spread across hectres of hilly terrains and beautifully maintained. The entering price is quite steep for tourist (1100Lakhs per person) as compared to locals (50Lakhs). It is not as magnificent as those botanical garden in some part of the world that I have been but it has numerous type of plants, ranging from medicinal plants, cold climate colorful flowers and very old aged mature trees. Due to its large area, the stroll can be quite tiring especially when we walked along the small rocky paths. If you need to get a buggy however, it is available at 1000Lakhs per hour but the number of buggy is very limited. My mom and her friend waited almost 1 hour for any available buggy but failed. There are upper gardens and lower gardens. We lost track of our whereabouts but we first encountered Rose Garden. Since it is May and it is spring, there are many blossom colourful roses. Red (definitely), pink, white, blue, yellow etc. The Japanese garden is nothing to shout about with its water features and some unimpressive bonsai. Probably can skip it if you are not up for a long uphill stroll. This place is a good diversion of the busy Nuwara Eliya town but it comes with high price and the garden is not really spectacular. It is still a good place for relaxing stroll with family, but definitely not for those with weak knees or legs. Unless you are lucky and there is available buggy for you to rent.

Located in one of the highest spots in Sri Lanka, thus covered with mist during the evening hours (usually). It is a pleasant surprise to find some rare species of plants and flowers in the mist. The foot path may be muddy if rain disturbs you, but you can simply turn back to the main walk ways which are properly built. You can further take the assistance of a guide if you wish. Best time to visit is March / April & May, during morning hours.

Hakgala Botanical Garden is one of the three botanical gardens in Sri Lana. The other two being Peradeniya Botanical Garden and Henarathgoda Botanical Garden. It is the second largest garden in Sri Lanka. The garden is contiguous to Hakgala Strict Nature Reserve in Nuwara Eliya. The gardens is believed to be the highest set botanical gardens in the world. Hakgala Gardens is open daily from 8.00 am to 5.30 pm. Plant nursery closes at 3.00 pm. Wheel chairs are available for hire at a nominal rent. Although light motor vehicles are permitted to enter the gardens, visitors are advised to walk around Hakgala gardens if they wish to explore the many beautiful places in this very compact garden. We spent a good 4 hours at the garden and enjoyed every bit of it and also bought plants from the nursery. Please note that the plant nursery closes at 3.30 pm. The garden is open on all days from 8.00 am to 5.30 pm.
a beautiful collection of many species of trees and flowers and a must visit for the botanical stream student. A better one is at Peradeniya Kandy but here there is better

Located on the main A5 road south of the central Sri Lankan hill town of Nuwara Eliya is the Hakgala Botanic Garden surrounded by spectacular mountain countryside The site contains several walks and would be fairly accessible to anyone with a mobility problem although there are one or 2 steep climbs and some tricky steps. The most important part of the Hakgala Botanic Gardens are the roses. There is also an interesting Japanese garden.
March is a Little early for a visit, because the roses are not yet flowering at this time. All the same it was worth the visit to see many other Flowers and especially many exotic big trees.

First of all, Google Maps claims this attraction is permanently closed.  It is not.  However, It's definitely not worth going to in my opinion. It is incredibly expensive for foreigners.  First, you have to pay a taxi or tuk tuk to take you there.  (We paid 700LKR).  Then, you have to pay 22 times the amount locals do.  For every foreigner, the price is 1100LKR.  Locals pay 50LKR.  We didn't go in because we felt that this difference is beyond reasonable.  I can't tell you if it was worth the price or not, but if you choose to go, be prepared to pay.
Entrance fee of 300 Rupees each and a nice stroll for a couple of hours.  Well kept gardens and lawns with interesting plants - worth a visit.

Any traveler visit to NUwaraeliya should visit Hakgala Botanic Gardens as well. This is not just garden it has long history. It has established in 1861. Very colorful garden with different kind of plantations and flowers. Important thing is Travelers not allow to brig any "polythene bags".
All types of flora and fauna (if your lucky!).. A lovely peaceful walk through nature at its best. It could be better if it was a bit more organised and the tickets cost less!

Well the gardens are always beautiful but Hakgala clearly have more space to improve ... especially with regard to toilet facilities and food facilities ... but its a beautiful place, and if you are going that way don't forget to stop and enjoy the beauty of nature ...
Green natural beautiful colorful flowers in cold climate. I don't have any more words to describe. Lovely place. Better season these days to enjoy sunny days

Visited Hakgala Botanjcal Gardens after quite some time. Lot of improvements signages things made easy for visitors.April is the best time to visit Hakgala when the flowers bloom and climate is really good.Spent some quality time with a group of relatives at the garden. Nice to hear that the park authorities are planning to develop the pond which according to Ramayana Sita while being held captive by Ravana used for bathing. The pond situated at the highest point of the Hakgala Botanical Garden will be a main attraction once developed and accesible for tourists.Seen some nice tropical flowers blooming..
Flowers starting to bloom, nice place to stroll and perhaps read a book, under a huge old tree. Pity we were not allowed to take a picnic basket .

This is a beautiful Botanical garden near Sita temple .The entrance fee for foreigners is too high when compared to the LOWER Flower garden,Rock garden, glass house,Uppr flower garden, Fernery,Roe and spice garden are certain important places not to be missed. We have seen ASHOKA TREE and flowers as the tree is related to RAMAYANA , under which SITA was living during the days of captivity in LANKA.
The botanical garden is well maintained and has very beautifully landscaped, we had lunch inside the park  and it was very enjoyable . a must see place is  the â€œJapanese gardenâ€

We visited the Botanical Gardens mainly from a birdwatching perspective but were delighted by what we found in general. The layout and displays of the collections was very impressive indeed and a visit is highly recommended. I was particularly taken with the fernarium which was fabulous to behold. walking around the whole park is recommended but the steep hills can make your calves ache a little, especially if you're the wrong side of sixty, as we are. General facilities were a little lacking in comparison with fairly basic restrooms and limited catering on site. Also, it is quite expensive in Sri Lankan terms at Rs 1100 for foreign visitors. The birdwatching here was excellent also, which made me even happier. If visiting at weekends or around national holidays do get here as early as possible because when the crowds begin to appear it can become noisy and not so much fun.

The botanic gardens are a very quiet and tranquil place to relax from all the chaos and noice. It is located just a few kilometers outside of Nuwara Eliya - we took a bus for 30 rupees. The admission was 1100 rupees, but it was worth it.

Hakgala is a large well planned colonial botanical gardens that are beautifully tended, immaculately planted and a wonderful oasis close to Nuwara Eliya in the Sri Lankan hills. The gardens are obviously loved by the staff and will take about 2-3 hours to enjoy. Recommened.

One of the best maintained Botanical gardens of Sri lanka. 2-3 hours visit will be enough to taste the beauty. Close to Nuwara Eliya town. Weekends are normally packed with local crowd. Please remember to take bottle of water with you. Nice view of the valley.
Not cheap admission but well worth it. There's acres to see and all so beautiful. There's monkeys and wildlife . Different areas are set out differently, a lovely restful area .

The Hakgala Botanical Gardens and the Kandy Botanical Gardens are our two favourite gardens in Sri Lanka. They are widely different in altitude and therefore offer different, but equally interesting, ranges of flora. It was nice to see how many Sri Lankans there were there enjoying the gardens and how well the gardens were being kept.

This is one of the most valuable places in Sri Lanka and if someone is not visiting this place in his/her tour to Nuwara Eliya is like uncompleted tour. There are plenty of very rear & un common flowers,plants,trees in this garden.Some trees I have seen for the first time & specially good for children to learn & study about flowers,plants and trees. Responsible care takers looking after this garden like their own kids.They are maintaining this garden very nicely.We should really salute for those care takers in the garden.That is not enough we must help them by not destroying any flowers,plants. There were too much monkeys in the garden and notice that some areas with bad smells.Some kind of action must be taken by the authorities. Recommended to all of you to visit this garden & feel the nature.You will love to visit more & more times.

Hakgala botanical garden is one of my favorite gardens for the simple fact that there are small quite marvelous gardens tucked into quite unexpected places which gives an overall sense of a sort of an adventurous trip. this visit was after about ten years and it was hearting to discover the charming old garden was still there with its quaint summer huts and English style willow tress. there has been lot of improvement mostly involving paving foot paths and walkways and some of it still going on. as we visited in December there was not much flowers but the wonderful weather and the quietness due to less crowds made up to it. The season for flowers is from March to August.

As per our itinerary, we visited Hakgala Botanic Gardens which is situated on the Nuwara Eliya-Badulla main road, 16 kms from Nuwara Eliya.  As the Garden is situated at an altitude of about 5500 feet above the Mean Sea Level,. it has a cool temperate climate. The Garden is spread over a vast area and is famous for number of species of Orchids and Roses.  It almost took two hours to just have a glance at the trees. Ashoka Trees are seen here. The entry fee  which is Rs.1100/- is abnormally high for foreign tourists. Above that, they are not accepting Indian Currency, US Dollors nor the Credit/Debit Card.  It is ridiculous that they only insist Sri Lankan Currency. There is a big disparity in the entrance fee between Sri Lankan Tourists and that of Foreigners.. Inside the  gardens, there are no shops nor restaurants. The Rose Garden was closed but it was not informed at the time of purchase of entry tickets. We were rather disappointed but this type of exploitation should be avoided..

We loved our visit to Hakgala Botanic Gardens! We spend around two hours exploring the different sections of the gardens. There were some incredible trees and plants from all over the world and the fern garden was amazing. There were few visitors the day we were there and it was wonderful wandering around feeling like we were along in this beautifully kept garden. Lot's of birds and we even saw a big black snake sleeping in the grass! Some of the views over the nearby hills are amazing. You feel like you are on top of the world! There is a bright and colourful Hindu temple on the road from Nuwara Eliya that is worth stopping to have a look at.
variety of trees and plants were there. Entrance fee was Rs.1100 for foreigners. It's ok to visit just once. Toilets were terrible. Park was clean

The gardens are well worth a visit, if you are interested in huge old trees from around the globe. Unfortunatly there are no litter bins, so local people just throw their litter on the ground. The staff do their best to keep it clean. Cost R1100 per foreign adult
Pretty gardens, but when we visited there was limited access to certain areas due to wasps and we found leeches on our shoes when we left. Otherwise lovely!

There were eight of us. Entrance fees is 1000 LKR so we spent 8000 LKR here. The landscape area is clean and we love the fresh air here. However, there is really not much to see here. The Rose Garden is pretty bare... I would advise you to spend the money elsewhere or on a meal...
Loved the variety of flowers and the way the garden is maintained. Doesn't excite me much since I have seen it before in India as well. If you are a flower enthusiast donot miss it .
Its not worth to visit due to high entrance fee you have to pay for this garden, not much to see & dirty bathrooms .

The botanical garden covers a large area and a map is provided of the different types of plantings.  Unfortunately it was raining but that did not detract from the mature trees, shrubs and flowers.  We walked round the perimeter of the garden and walked on the very narrow suspension bridge over the river.  We then criss crossed the gardens to ensure we saw everything.  It is very well kept by an army of gardeners and is a haven for courting couples wandering around.  There is a small cafe but for a decent cup of coffee there is a coffee bar near the exit.  A very peaceful environment.

column7: Vila Nova de Santo Andre, Portugal
column11: Another amazing place to visit and see most of the beauties of nature! It was a very good and nice walk around the gardens and so relaxing! We can say that we refilled our Â«human batteriesÂ», for some more years, with this visit!
Misty, cool yet beautiful... Very well kept and variety of flowers. Do not feed monkeys!! One of Best places in Sri Lanka for whom love nature..!!

Lots to see and view in this place - and I never thought I will say so about a botanical garden. Beautifully maintained and a huge variety of trees - flora and fauna on offer.Dont miss the fernery and cactus house and do stop by their resturant in the garden for freshening up. If lucky, you will bump into a snake charmer with King Cobra on its majestic display.

These gardens are spread across a large area of land and are very well kept. Each tree is labelled and there are several of vintage banyan trees. There is a seperate section for Aleo vera vegetation. The walk is very nice and there is a royal gardern cafe for some snacks. They have a facility of taking you around in a Golf cart - which needs to be booked in advance. Beware of monkeys around your path - there are a few and are harmless. This place is a must visit for its sheer beauty and expanse of greenery

Hakgala Botanical Garden is one of the 4 Botanical Gardens in Sri Lanka. The well maintained loans; flowers from different countries; Trees from different continents; Ponds, small forest patches are ideal habitat for beautiful bird species and butterflies. The opening time is from 8 am to 5.30 pm, and need to purchase a ticket about 5 $. Other important things in the Garden: Plant nursery to sell plants, seed store to sell seed, a local canteen etc. We went there in a morning time on a field trip of Ornithology Group. Managed to see following rare and attractive birds: Scimitar Babbler, Sri Lanka White-eye, Grey Wagtail, Canary Flycatcher, Velvet-fronted Nuthatch, Tickell's Blue Flycatcher, Great tit, Purple-rumped Sunbirds, Rock Pigeon, etc.
It is amazing to think how much effort they are putting in to maintain this gem. Don't forget to visit the "Fernary" and feel free to climb up the hill. You will not regret.

Visited this beautiful flower garden. It was much chilly early hours of the morning. Flowers were beautiful. Above is the Hakgala Strict Nature reserve. We heard the call of Sri Lanks Spur fowl from very close by but we were not fortunate enough to see them. Any way they are very shy birds. Beside this we spotted quite a number of Birds here. Looking forward to re visit in April during which most of the blossoming  will take place and it will not be that cold then!.

This is not the 1st time I have visited the place, but compare to my old memories the place is far better than past. October is not the best time to visit this park, but still there are lot of flowers and place is well maintained. Only problem I had was parking since the vehicle parking facility is limited outside of the premises. There is a little cafeteria and place to buy seeds/plants if you are interested. Lot to walk so be ready for that.

The garden is located on Badulla road 10 k m from Nuwara Eliya at altitude of 6000 ft. It is put up under the Hakgala peak ( Jaw Rock ) by the English during 1860' s. There is a story that the garden was brought from Himalayas in India by Hanuman . There are various species of trees, plants and flowers systematically grown and maintained by qualified and trained gardeners. English Oak  , Himalayan Pines ,Japanese Cedars , Californian Monetary Cypress are some . There are trees planted by  celebrities  . There is an ornamental pond and summerhouse also. We moved around in an electric car. It was a half day informative recreation , to be at the highest botanical garden in the world !

10 km on the Badulla Road.The Garden was first established in 1860 under the curatorship of three Britishers of the same name - William Nock, JK Nocl and JJ Nock. It lies under the Hakgala Peak, between 5000-6000 feet in elevation - the highest set Botanical Gardens in the world. It boasts 100 year old Monetary Cypress trees from California, Japanese Cedars, Himalayan Pines and English Oak.
Compared to Peradeniya botanical gardens, Hakgala is nothing much.  Near the entrance to the park is filthy with rubbish thrown everywhere.  There was a foul smell of badly kept drains.
If you're a plants and flowers enthusiast, it's really nice. If you don't want to pay to see pretty trees and flowers, then don't bother.
Enjoyed seeing local children experience the garden; even the young men were photographing the trees and flowers.
We went 3 weeks ago good for nature lovers. Beautiful views and flowers.Make sure u need at least 3 hours to view this garden and u have to walk a lot.
Well maintained, plant and flower variety is vast. Best time to visit would be April, but tends to be over crowded. June is another good time, a drizzle might be bothersome though. Last visited 2013

Nice and well maintained botanical garden. Same entrance fee than in Peradeniya garden. As the climate is quite cold in winter, there's no much exotic plants but it's very quiet (no much visitors) and very well maintained.

This Garden is so pretty for me they have lots of variety od plants ,flower ,ferm, And etc.. its so peacefull nice to walk And And looking around to see the Beauty of this garden dont miss this place if your coming to Nuwerlya..

The garden is beautiful and filled with flowers. There is lot of things to see and long ways to walk. Canteen is very small with very low facilities and little varieties of food. Sometimes you get exhausted to find the correct return path.

The location of the Garden is very beautiful. However, the layout of the Flora is not very good. I felt that they have random planted all the Flora making it look too cramped. The beauty of the plants is not shown due to this. The Botanic Garden has a lot of scope for improvement and can be turned into a very beautiful Garden.

Quite expensive but was lovely walking around seeing what plants from all over the world were grown here, many massive old trees from Australia could be found. Very peaceful gardens and a nice change to walk around and experience it.

Wonderful garden. You can see a variety of flora & fauna. Best during March to May, but you will have to compensate with the large crowd during this period, specially in April. You must be prepared to spend the whole day to explore & enjoy the whole of the extent of the garden. It is rather amazing to creep though the ferny area under big grown Tree Ferns, which will definitely give you a taste of Jurassic Park.
